The Spektr-RG spacecraft is equipped with two advanced X-ray telescopes, the German eROSITA and the Russian ART-XC. These telescopes are designed to capture high-energy X-ray photons emitted by some of the most energetic phenomena in the universe, such as black holes, supernova remnants, and galaxy clusters.

The spacecraft follows a highly elliptical orbit around the Earth, reaching altitudes of up to 1.5 million kilometers, which allows it to optimize its observing time and avoid interference from the Earth's atmosphere and magnetic field. 

As it surveys the sky, the spacecraft detects X-ray photons and measures their energy, providing scientists with unprecedented views of these energetic phenomena. The data collected by Spektr-RG will be used to create maps of the X-ray sky, identifying new sources of X-ray emission and improving our understanding of the formation and evolution of structures in the universe.

Overall, the Spektr-RG spacecraft is revolutionizing our understanding of the most extreme and energetic objects in the universe, and providing new insights into the physics of the cosmos.
